question: What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.

comments.comment: It's not for me, but I appreciate the medium for those who enjoy it. I know people earn livings this way and I support them fully.
i have a positive opinion on them, it looks like it opens many doors for them and I also enjoy watching their content and their product's recommendations. some of them have really good content.

I don't personally relate or identify with this specific job/career choice but I understand why it is becoming widespread. It seems fitting given the proliferation of social media in the last decade or so.
They are doing something they like to do and have the convenience of doing it online at their own convenience. Many are fortunate to make very good income.

I think it makes sense that being an internet influencer is now seen as a real profession, since so many people rely on them for ideas, advice, and entertainment. They play a big role in shaping trends and connecting with audiences in a way traditional jobs don’t. At the same time, I feel it’s important for the space to stay authentic and responsible.
I find influencers to be annoying. They do not seem to be genuine and I find it silly that people are foolish enough to be affected by them.

Influencers are a great addition to the internet. Not only are they entertaining they have been informative about information that has not broadcast on the news. With this being said I believe this will be the new wave of how we actually get news in the truth.
It’s almost like celebrities in the 90s, there’s really no difference except influencers may be more down to earth and expose more of their personal life at first.

They entertain, pass knowledge and information to the masses, they're the new media houses. While it might seem new to a lot of people,  a number of streamers give insightful and cited information.  As well as entertain.

I think it’s very fun and sort of an easy way to get income all while just living your life. Of course having to keep up with trends after a while people tend to just start following one another. Everyone ends up having/wearing the same thing, no one likes to be creative anymore or unique.

It reminds me of the Tower of Babel in the Bible, the point where people begin to not understand each other anymore. Everyone is building their own brand of themselves, losing constant with each other, while thinking that they are building this one collective mind. I find it disturbing.

I think it's becoming saturated. Everyone now thinks they have something profound to say, everyone wants to chase what others have done. I think it's depressing to watch how everyone thinks they are so unique and important, building their own brand, it reminds me lately of the Tower of Babel in the Bible but I can't explain it in such few characters.

I believe that it is a difficult job to do, but that it is a very crowded profession. I am not sure it is a great benefit to society as a whole, but the Internet addiction of many will keep it funded. Live streaming of one's life has shown to have a negative effect since they often need to be outrageous to gather the views over others.
I think that it has its placed, considering we all value entertainment in the form of TV, or books. It's just another offshoot of the entertainment industry, but more easily accessible by people.
They're OK. But there are too many of them now. They also are mostly fake.
Internet influencers have opened up a world of information. I think they are a good source of information and entertainment. They may have some flaws, but I find them to be beneficial in many ways.

I believe internet influencers exploded during covid when everyone was on lockdown and it became more of a recognized professions these past 2-3 years. Many people think it's easy money or they want to pursue their passion of content creation and once they get enough followers and go viral, they quit their full time jobs and start doing content creation full time.

Influencers becoming a recognized profession is a natural evolution of media and commerce. It reflects a shift in how people consume content and make purchasing decisions, moving from traditional advertising to more personalized and relatable recommendations. While it offers new opportunities for creative individuals, it also raises questions about authenticity, transparency, and the potential for oversaturation in the digital marketplace.
I feel it is a good job but has a lot of responsibility. Influencers should be cognizant of their audience and potential to influence their lives. Behave responsibly.

I do not think it is the best thing at the moment because I feel like people can get the wrong ideas about success from such cases. I also feel like there are probably comparatives that existed in this country that were around long before there was even an internet.
I think it’s great that the everyday person can gain a platform and be relatable to different audiences.
I think it isn't too surprising because a lot of creators are popular. They also seem to make good money from it.
I don’t think they are bad, it’s not easy being famous off those platforms. As a recognized profession, I think they should be made accountable like other profession does.
I think some use their popularity for good and some let the recognition get to their head and they become people no one wants to associate with.

I think it makes sense since a lot of people spend time online and creators can actually make a living from it now. It’s similar to entertainment jobs, just on new platforms. As long as they put in real work, I see it as a valid profession.

I am totally fine with it. I do think they should be willing to make sure that they take accountability for the things that they say though, seeing as how the profession is not as regulated as many other professions are

I think at the very least, streamers and some video creators are currently supplementing and to a limited degree replacing standard news outlets. Many news outlets are preset in what they will say based on a diverse mixup of staff leaning either left or right, making it much harder to find with you. Streamers and Video creators are much more plentiful and precise; By this logic, Its a viable profession path If you can get inital publicity, via signing up with a streaming group. Thats my thoughts
I see it as a great profession. It gives these creators source of money

I think it's pretty cool that people are able to make money from home on the internet by blogging, streaming, etc. However I also think it's important to teach kids that being on the internet isn't just "easy money" and that it's still important to go to college or learn a trade and not rely solely on the internet as a career.

I think it’s awesome. I love following certain influencers who I can personally relate to and I also like that it doesn’t matter what you are promoting or what you’re focusing on there’s a place for everybody as far as being a recognized profession how cool is that that you  get to share your life and beliefs and get paid for it.
I like to watch them demonstrate new products. I also look for recommendations from them.
I think they have become industry changers and movers. They have changed how advertisement and product promotion is done as well as political and social narratives online.

I think it's kind of weird how invested people are in others' lives to the point of paying these streamers to create content, but I suppose it makes sense that it would be starting to become a recognized profession. I don't think it should be, but at the same time, some people dedicate their lives to creating Youtube content for a living, too.

I think it's great that the internet has given people opportunities they never would have had otherwise. People are able to work from anywhere as an influencer. It's enabled more people to access entertainment and information easier than ever before.

Yes social media videos are basically replacing Television, which is really dying. I think it's a fantastic thing, because it democratizes who gets to become a celebrity and make a good living from it. I don't want a cabal of evil, super rich globalist scumbags to decide who we can and can't watch.
Problematic when viewers solely get their news from internet influencers. Then subsequently regurgitate  the streamer's viewpoints in a uncritical fashion.
Like everything it has it’s good and bad, good because  we can learn things or they can use their platforms to spread awareness ,bad because it’s easier to misuse their platforms to misinformation.

I think internet influencers becoming a recognized profession is sort of silly but at the same time it does take effort to keep audiences entertained and having to edit videos is not easy. It's not something a kid should aspire to become but it could work as a side gig/hustle, it should not be a main job for anyone in my opinion.

I think if people can figure out a way to succeed in it, good for them. People exploit themselves for money everyday and this isn’t a new concept, it’s just the first time it’s being capitalized and documented to this extent.
I think it's good that people can become entrepreneurs. They help out ordinary people.

I think it's great that more and more people are becoming influencers because the more people become influencers, the more competition there is for better content, more accurate content, and so forth. For example, the more beauty and skincare influencers there are, the more competitive it becomes to create accurate, entertaining, and professional skincare and beauty content for the viewers.
I think it's a unique profession! Unfortunately, the way the internet is monetized is very detrimental, especially to younger audiences.

It is ridiculous the amount of money these folks make as compared to more traditionally "respectable" jobs, like doctor, engineer, etc. I believe influencers and creators promote excessive overconsumption.
It's fine that it's a profession, but I don't think many of them have the best interest of others at heart. I think many of them are in it just for grifting money off their fans.
I think its great for people to be self employed and have others ways to make money besides corporate America.  It also gives other people a perspective and influence from someone like them.
Rather than encouraging future children to pursue studies, research, or more advanced careers, they will be more drawn to easy and stimulating things like influencers.

I understand that they put in a lot of work to make their content, but It seems like a copout job for kids that are now growing up. Kids want to take the easy route to making a living instead of going to college.

As a person who watched the web crawl, then sprint, I see influencers as a real trade: part entertainer, part marketer, part small business owner (with all the headaches). Done with integrity, it widens who gets paid for creative labor, grows culture, and builds communities; the catch is that algorithms behave like fickle bosses, so creators need fair contracts, unions, and safety nets. Teach media literacy, require transparency about ads and AI, and I’m comfortable calling it a profession.

I agree with internet influencers such as streamers, bloggers, short video creators as becoming more increasingly more recognized as an actual profession because they generate income from providing this form of publicized entertainment. An internet influencer such as Mr. Beast starts has created a life based on their internet antics and often by doing this, it can create large streams of incomes from the vast number of followers and watchers of this individual's widely popular streaming content.
My opinion on internet influencers is that I think they like the attention. I think that they are people that are  extroverts.

To be an internet influencer you need to be so insanely lucky, that I don't think it is a viable option for literally 99.99% of the population.  It anything it should be something more akin to a side hustle, and not the main pursuit for literally anyone. It is probably on the level of winning the lottery in luck needed to become an influencer. As for it being a profession, it should be recognized as a profession. It is a job where a person needs to put in a certain amount of work.
I think it's something we've seen before but in a more accessible form. YouTubers used to be a big thing, but now we've moved toward Tiktok and Instagram content.
I think it’s great. It gives them an opportunity to make money and teach and audience.
I dislike them because they’re just attention seeking people who say anything for some social media engagement. They have no actual influence over anyone with half a brain.
I think some internet influencers are genuine and others are so fake. The fake ones make the rest look bad, so it makes it hard to believe who is genuine and who isn’t.

I think it is great that people are able to put themselves out there and share their ideas. I think being an influencer is a great way to make a living without having to get an education, which can be very expensive.
There is a lot of them now and more ways to earn online. Sponsorships have really changed how people view the profession.

At first, I was a bit skeptical at the validity of it being a job. I didn't understand how someone could realistically make enough money to live just by having "followers" and promoting products. Currently, I think that having that opportunity to make a living from the internet is a great opportunity and one that many people would want to accomplish. It doesn't seem easy or a well formed path, but one that is worth going down if you can commit.
It's great that influencers are getting more recognition. There are many hats worn for this particular profession and it shouldn't be downplayed as being a lesser job for the freedom it grants.
I think that it is a valid profession. Many of them provide great news updates and access to information for the public.

I'm conceptually fine with it, as I believe a quality content creator provides a lot of value and entertainment, as well as generate actual discussion around unconventional topics. That being said, it's also mired in slop and click-baiting with undeserving idiots garnering a platform.
I think it's annoying. They make lots of money just being on Youtube. People follow them mindlessly.
i think its a joke. They spread misinformation. And are paid to spread misinformation

The emergence of internet influencers as a recognized profession showcases the digital landscape's evolution. Creators can now monetize their passions, building careers, but this shift also sparks discussions about sustainability, responsibility, and industry standards, highlighting the complexity and multifaceted nature of this growing profession. New opportunities abound.

I think it can be good because it creates new jobs, especially since a lot of people are complaining that AI is taking over everyone's jobs. But there are risks to it because some of these influencers may use their platform for malicious purposes, and if they have a large enough platform, it can be harmful to society.
There are several internet influencers that I follow and genuinely enjoy. I am ok with it being known as a profession but is not something that should be considered sustainable in terms of a career.
I think that some are very good that usually share something about their lives that many want to view. Others seem like attention-seeking narcassists.

I find it fascinating! I’ve noticed that it is a very high-risk, opportunistic job that varies widely in both effort and success. However, I find it very comparable to other jobs in the entertainment industry, such as performative arts. The increasing demand for video content provides people with interesting ways to make a living from pursuing their own hobbies, some of which may be otherwise difficult to market

I am happy that everyone can have their five minutes of fame with social media and internet influencing. It gives a platform for common people to exhibit their artistic talents. However I feel the influencers have to diversify in order to remain relevant in this ever changing landscape. Mental health of the creators and the mindless scrolling of the audience are aspects to be concerned about.
I think they are very much needed in today's media landscape. They can bridge the gap between institutions and the news.

In my opinion, the rise of influencers as a recognized profession reflects a fundamental shift in how people consume media and build careers. It's an entrepreneurial path that validates personal brands and content creation, though it comes with unique challenges like job security and constant public scrutiny.

I am not thrilled about it, because I think the low barrier to entry and the fickle nature of the algorithm has allowed people who are not producing anything substantive to monetize their efforts. There are talented creators, but I don't think all of these people are contributing meaningfully to society.

I feel there are a few influencers I like that I feel are genuine and have actual talent as creators, or at the bare minimum an actual voice of their own. But I feel a lot of that culture/sub-culture is not genuine at all. From fashion to self help, and etc. Or just commentary in general. It feels so clean and safe.
It's a legitimate profession in that people can and do make money from it, but I don't think it's a viable career choice for the majority of the population.

I think that as long as it is done responsibly that there is no problem with it. People have a right to make money however they want as long as it is legal. This is just the new wave of opportunity that people are taking.
I don't trust them. You can't be sure the person is actually using the product and has gotten real results.

I like that they are able to show their creative side. I also think that they can help people that are going through similar problems by sharing what they share on the internet. I think it is good to have entertainment and people that you feel you can relate too.

There are many that are just so good, and if it weren't for the internet, and the ability for anyone to be creative and be seen online, we wouldn't know they existed. I think it's great that people can be recognized for their talents and make a living doing it.

I think there is a good and bad regarding influencers. I think they can both be useful and pointless, depending on who it is and who sponsors them. They can be a good influence or bad towards their platforms; whoever looks up to them or follows them.
I am older but I love this as a profession. It takes creativity, content and communication skills to be a great influencer.
I don't follow or care about internet influencers. It's not something I even think about, frankly.
i think it is a joke.  These people are paid to put out an opinion

I like many of the influencers on social media and online in general. They share many of their skills and knowledge on so many topics, and I learned a lot from them. Also, with the status of the economy today, using this means as a source of income/profession is a great idea, because of rise in unemployment. This is a means to take care of ourselves and our families.

I don't have a strong opinion on it. It is a little worrisome that anyone with a camera can say what they want and if they have a strong enough following people will listen. However it is a good way to connect with an audience and some influencers seem more authentic than others.
They live fake lives. They portray themselves to the world like they have such a great life, but they hide what's really going on in their lives behind the scenes.

I enjoy content creators, however even though technically they do influence... I dont like the name "influencer" because some of us can consume content and just enjoy it or be entertained or get SOMETHING from it withOUT being "influenced". Hate that term. Content Creators NOT Influencers.

I don't have any strong opinions on influencers becoming increasingly recognized as a real profession but I do think that it's important that it is recognized that they are essentially paid sponsors.  I think that it's really important that because of this, people don't just take their recommendations as real truth without looking into what they are saying further.  It is important that people look to actual experts on things like health and facts rather than just believing influencers.

I think as someone who grew up a lot with video games, and popular youtubers like pewdiepie. I enjoy it that doing something you love a lot, can be recognized a an actual profession, where you can make a lot of money as well. As a content creator you constantly have to make new content to keep your audience interested as well.

I think it's kind of silly, but I can also respect it. People enjoy media, and it's just an extension of tv or movie stars at this point. However, because it feels more interactive than standard celebrities, I can see why it's popular.

I think that I do see it as a serious profession being a streamer. The amount of time it takes to put together and research that goes into making a video could be hours to maybe even days. The education to learn how to both a film and edit is a skill you could use in a regular nine to five job.
I like the idea. It help get the idea of different products and the options  about thing out there that can be relatable.
If people watch and subscribe to their videos and they can make enough money, I can see no problem with this.  And the way the job market is going, you may see a lot more of this happening
I feel that internet influencers are only supporting brands and products to receive a monetary or product benefit.  I do not trust anything that is said by an influencer.
I am not overly impressed with internet influencers personally. Depending on what the person is blogging about some content can be considered interesting I suppose.
I think it's stupid. They own a camera so everyone should follow them?

I don't watch any influencers. From what I understand these people are online giving their opinions on various topics or are trying to get you to buy something. I don't think they are experts. I wouldn't depend on them myself.
I'm not a huge fan of influencers, but I believe that they are legitimate profession. They generate business for various companies and many completely support themselves through it.

I think some of them can become helpful for some people so it can be a good thing. However, some are bad where impressionable kids are watching and doing stupid dangerous stuff. So IF you call yourself a professional internet influencer etc you should be held accountable for the bad things that you cause.
I think if the influencers can make a living doing it, is fine. As long as they are telling the truth and no misrepresenting any of the products or services they are advertising
It is a way to earn money. Before there were snake oil sellers, now we have internet influencers. Just like with the snake oil sellers, this group of people should be rejected.
I don't think this is a valid profession.  These are just people voicing their opinions.
I think that they are the perfect salesperson. Usually regular people whi are just like me who are trying new things and giving recommendations.  As long as they are honest, it's honest work.
I find it interesting how much power they are given by society. I think it is ridiculous, but I understand the desire to be popular and to also get paid for it .... Well, it's crazy!

I think that it’s a good thing. It opens doors for so many kids who don’t want to go to college or go the traditional route for work. It gives people motivation that even a regular people can make a good amount of money if your funny with a camera

Good on them for doing something they enjoy and turning it into a way to make money. Those who put their family members at risk or exploit others should not be recognized, but that's not a large percentage of them.

I think it is rather silly, as I mostly care about the opinions of experts in areas I am interested in, and not what some random individual with a microphone and a penchant for self-promotion has to say about anything.

When it comes to influencers, I'm not a huge fan. Typically, they're fake and self-absorbed, and a LOT of them are just overall awful people. However, so are politicians, and that's a real career; I don't have any issue with influencing being considered a real career, I just refuse to interact with the content.
My thing is short form influencers are toxic. It’s bad for general environment.

I am not a big fan of influencers at all. I don't understand how many acquire their notoriety and what qualifies them. I'm sure there are situations where an influencer is an expert worth listening to, but my general opinion is that is not the case.

I think internet influencers becoming a recognized profession is a logical progression of work in todays ever-evolving digital environment. I think the reason it is being recognized as a profession is because so many people have learned to monitize streaming and short video creation. It is viewed as a profession because more and more influencers are now using content creation as their sole means of generating income.

I don’t entirely think it’s bad. Some of them are legitimately producing entertaining or instructional videos that are no different from other forms of media, so I think it’s fine if they’re successful.

I think people need to understand that only a small percentage of influencers are able to make a comfortable living doing that. Most will not be able to provide for themselves solely doing that. And I honestly do not believe it is a "real" profession.
I think it is a good thing because it gives people more options to make money. Yes, it has positives and negatives but overall a great field for independent content creators.
It's difficult to view internet influencers as a legitimate profession.  There is no formal training or education involved and very few guidelines in place that would qualify this as a career.
I feel like they are really good people a lot of the time, but if you have them hide behind the screens and a horrible people to a lot of individuals and the horrible things

I feel conflicted as that is a path I wanted, and still do want to pursue to an extent, but I also think there is an ultimately finite number of roles in the field and serious concerns can arise from it on a societal level.
there are too many and they are often annoying. sometimes they are fake and only interested in money
If the influencer is not lying and trying to deceive anyone it's fine. There are many that I am not a fan of. It's just a way for them to sell stuff.

I think it’s become extremely oversaturated. I think it was better when YouTube was bigger and there was people on YouTube who became big vloggers, like for example Amanda Steele. I think with so many people becoming influencers now it’s created an even worse culture of over consumption of goods. Also, children now a days mainly want to be streamers/ vloggers/ influencers as their job when they’re older, which I think is bad because it creates more of a focus on looks and goods over personality and smarts.

It isn't what it started out to be, now there are so many content creators using others work. No one is doing their own research, one content creator does a story or topic, shortly there after you have ten other creators piggbacking on that one story.
I dislike them and that it it has become a "profession."  It is a blight on society.  People think they can just do that.  It amplifies toxicity and vanity.
I generally dislike them. While a few make interesting content, I find most to be vapid, boring, cringey or all of the above.

I think they are an absolute detriment to true information legitimacy.  Their ascendance blurs the line between truth and sensationalism, as well as making viewer attention spans increasingly shorter.
If you can make money doing it more power to you.  That is the American way.  You can find a way to make money do it.

I have mixed feelings when it comes to influencers and them making this there main profession. I think there are some really talented influencers that deserve the fame and money they get. However there's a vast number of pretty people that don't have any real talent that somehow make money because the way they look.
I think for some it is a viable profession. There are some great channels out there that make great education content. I think am in favor of people trying it if they want.
I guess that can be called a profession especially since people are getting paid to create these short videos and being an influencer certainly has it ups of being a recognized person around a brand.

I believe it is a bit much the way some people are making a living by being influencers. There is nothing wrong with being an influencer but I believe some people are being exploited by making moeny this way.
I try not to spend a lot of time watching these videos. Some are just a waste of time

I honestly am not a fan of it because I think it has become so oversaturated and most of these people don't actually put a lot of work into their content anymore. For example, there are a lot of TikTokers that don't do much besides vlog what they eat in a day, when there was once a time where Youtubers had to work hard to make money and actually provide content that viewers wanted to watch.
I don't think there is anything wrong with it if they are actually passionate about what they do. I feel like some of these influences will do anything to make money and aren't truly genuine.
I find it to be a perfectly fine profession. The main intent b3hind their work is in advertising so that is where I find they are worthy of the money they make.

Influences like all media have a few gems, generally mired in a giant pile of garbage, but the pile is larger.  So while there are a very small percentage that are worthwhile, it's probably not worth it to dig through the refuse.
I am still getting used to internet influencers being a recognized profession. I think it will become okay but right now it still feels a bit weird. Hopefully they can be helpful for people.
I do not think of these as professions, even though for the selected few the pay is very good.  It is at most a well paying gig with a limited time span.

I feel that this is a genuine job that should be considered a profession. There is a certain talent to become recognized by a large population of strangers and maintain popularity during streaming and entertaining. Furthermore, streamers often have to do more outside of recording videos to maintain their brand, often including editing, posting on multiple forums, networking, and engaging with audiences.

I am fine with internet influencers becoming recognized as a profession, as many of them perform the job of entertaining that other professions do such as comedians or talk show hosts. They could review food, make jokes, or discuss politics like famous people do on TV. As such, they should be recognized for that work as a profession.
I am not a huge fan of them. I find that their personalities are fake and unattractive.
I have no problem with it if that's what people can make money. People are obviously interested in spending time watchiing them and they are creating content.
It sounds like an exhausting thing to do. You're always trying to create content. You're always on the precipice of being irrelevant
I think it is okay, I find a lot of creators more entertaining than tv sometimes. I think people should be more open minded about it.

I'm honestly of two minds with this. On the one hand I strongly support anyone that can find a way to make money without the daily grind of a 9 to 5. On the other hand I think that they are starting to crowd each other out a bit and some of them are just not much value, but then again those not valuable will weed themselves out I suppose.

I think its nice, but it should remain a hobby first for most people. The odds of making it big in one these is astronomically low. But it being a profession makes sense since i now see some streamers in ads.
I do not watch internet influencers and have no desire to do so.  I am not sure that I consider this to be a profession.
i think its sort of good. Except some of them are known for doing rude things to people to become viral
It makes authenticity rare because most will be reviewing things, giving opinions etc for monetary reasons. Other than that I don't feel strongly about it.

If there is a need for it and the influencers can earn an honest living from it, then I'm not against it. I personally don't follow any influencers and am not a big fan of them. I would rather independently research anything I'm interested in rather than listen to the opinion of someone paid to promote the item, service, or brand.
I think it's a threat to creativity and individuality. It promotes wasteful buying and extreme and incorrect ideas. It makes the world more divided.

I don't inherently mind it unlike alot of people who have a knee jerk reaction to them. I support the ones who are entertaing, original and aren't harmful to society. I like the ones who teach you things or give you knowledge.
Won't last to long. For most, make the money while you can I say
I think it is a scam. If wifi was to shut down right now, all of those jobs would be null and void
I feel that, in general, they are not useful to society. While some cane be entertaining, there are many others that are harmful / help spread bad information.
They don’t interest me. Most seem to be little more than money generating entities.

For the most part I consider it the new form of celebrity, similar to movie and television stars of the past, or if we were to go further back radio personalities or even vaudville acts. The only real downside I see to it is the parasocial relationships people are developing with influencers and the amount of weight people place in influencers' opinions.
I used to be supportive of internet influencers becoming a recognized profession, but I'm not anymore. They are overpaid and I don't like that they are always pushing products for profit.

I think it would be good if they got recogonized as a real profession as it makes good money and is good for all. I think it's a valid position to try to get and show be shown its legit to older people who might be unfamiliar.

I think they are trying to influence the public at large but are not necessarily the correct way of thinking. They are feeding the public a lot of misinformation that the public doesn't know it is true.
Times have changed and individuals have way more power concerning their future and making their opinions known.  It is up to the listener to decide whether to click on their content or not.

I think it’s a lazy way to make a living since they spend very little time online in regards to the amount of money they may possible make.  Also, think it’s a bit narcissistic. Calling it a profession is a real joke to me.
they are successful entertainers, so I suppose it is okay, although on first glance it is weird to me. But if they have enough followers I guess they are successful entertainers.
It provides others a service that others are obviously okay with. Therefore I'm all for it. Just seems like a person in an advertisement
I think that its great and a creative way to make money. Aslong as they're putting out creative new content I think its entertaining. I support it.

I think that people want to get attention so they post a lot on social media and they have seen how easy it is to go viral and make money of content creation. They are also addicted to screens so they consume content all the time too. This kind of stuff is very lucrative for companies in general whether it be social media companies or just any company trying to advertise something.
In many cases, it seems ridiculous that people pay attention to influencers who may have little experience, knowledge or credibility. This does not seem to me to be a respectable profession.
They are more convincing and a new better way of convincing customers to make purchases.
I feel more power to them. If they have the energy and the vision to do something and be paid for it thats great. I would personally never do anything like what they do. But i hear that they like it.

As a profession, it has many flaws: content, control, and integrity. The content often seems outrageous; influencers may wrestle with sponsors for control, which can lead to compromised integrity. Does the message get lost within the desire for increased visibility?
I think it is a great profession.  They have to learn their skill and be creative to be successful.

I don’t see any inherent issues with it. I personally don’t find it’s for me, but if someone can make a living out of it and they are providing other people entertainment I or information that they find valuable, I say go for it! My issue lies with misinformation and malicious intent
I think that overall it's a good thing. In a world where many jobs are becoming more difficult to obtain, being able to invest oneself in a more creative endeavor is a benefit to all.
I think that it is unreal.  I am not a fan of influencers.  I do not think that it is a skill or that it is a sustainable "trade" for young people to be doing.
I've been observing this and I think it's a great way for companies to get their information out to the consumer.
It’s a new profession that developed out of the expansion of social media. The influencers have their place, but not everyone will get an audience and get rich from doing it.
They are doin a good job in that field. The internet influencers are greatly promoting products to a large online market globally.
I think it takes a lot of hard work and I respect the people that can do it make a living doing it
I believe that influencers add little or no value to society. They make tons of money to get people to buy products or form opinions. People often follow them like sheep.
It is good for the person that is earning money and if they get a lot of subscribers to their channel, they earned it.  If the can make money like this then it should be considered a profession.

I believe that online influencers' recognition as a profession illustrates how digital culture has impacted employment and entertainment.  While it provides artistic and financial benefits, it also poses questions about stability, authenticity, and long-term viability.  Overall, it demonstrates how internet platforms are altering society's definition of labor.

I think that it is good to a point as there have always been influencers in the world. The only downside is that more and more people are susceptible to being influenced due to the omnipresent nature of the internet and internet culture. There is also an overabundance of influencers these days.
I think it is cool that there are different new job opportunities for people with certain skills. I don't see a problem with it at all.

I personally don't follow any influencers, but I do agree that it can be a profession - especially for those who are handicapped or physically challenged.  This opens a door for them to be able to make a living.

I think it can be helpful for young people only if they promote healthy living. Think it’s becoming increasingly popular and it is not an easy profession. I do however think we need to promote less screen time for I struggle with mine too.
I think that influencers are a valuable asset in our society. They provide much needed and wanted reviews on products, opinions on cultural trends and products.

I think it’s too trendy and too many of them trying to make money off of being a social media influencer 
I would never follow anything like that

I think that is is as viable a profession as any other profession based in entertainment.  The internet has become a new medium in which entertainment is shared and it would be regressive to ignore this fact as it would hold back change and innovation in society.

Im very pro- streamer, bloggers and video creators! I sometimes find myself wishing i had the guts to do the same for a career because of how well they earn! But i lack creativity. I feel like they deserve all they have going on in their lifes at such a young age.
I think it's cool.  I hope the industry keeps growing and I would like to try it as well.
I think Internet influencers are fake and unrealistic. They tend to promote unrealistic standards, and I don't think they should have a platform nor be recognized in this profession.
I can see where this could be considered a profession. It is something that people can make a living at and also can influence people and they in turn can influence In turn can influence others.
My opinion is that the Internet has opened avenues for parasocial relationships which brings opportunities. It's a nascent form of communication and people can find connection.
I think it’s a short-term fad that will go away in time. The market is becoming saturated and new content is limited. They should enjoy the fame while it lasts.
I think in general its a good thing to enable people to get fame through different levels. Also allows me to have a job in the area that i work in.

These professions add a different perspective to media. 
I consider them to be akin to opinion and lifestyle reporters.
I would consider them to be recognized professions.
I feel that it’s a good thing because we’re gonna see a lot of content creators in the future. They aren’t going to be a slave to 9-5 jobs
I think it’s a valid occupation for someone who can do it successfully. Being an internet influencer also takes time, effort, and knowledge just like any other job.
I think it's fine that a person can make a living as an influencer. Depending on their followers, they can make a little, a lot, and everything in between.
I don't think that should necessarily be recognized as a profession.  It's nice that they are able to earn money doing what they do, but they likely will not have a long career doing it.

I think that they are often aesthetic but are driven by profit. It is important to discern what is an add and what they actually recommend. They get so much stuff for free it is unrealistic to keep up.
They all start to sounds the same. They are "obsessed" with every product they hawk, thus none of them are trustworthy. They are just ads, and very few stand out or can really sell the product.
I think its terrible. They say things that aren't true or proven by science.   They are just trying to get attention and make money

I think there are positives and negatives. On the one hand, it enables people who are outside of the prevailing mainstream view to present their information or news or viewpoints. On the negative side, influencers may not have the necessary expertise and they may give misleading or incorrect information which, at best is not helpful, or at worse, is harmful.
I am pretty neutral about it. I think it gives kids too much hope about it because it is way more rare than it seems to become popular enough to make enough money to replace a more traditional job.

I like some influencers When they  show 
 videos that teaches something valuable not just beauty tips.
I love influencers that teach you how to decorate your home.
I think it’s cool and very inspiring. I see them as hardworking and determined. It’s flexible and a more inclusive job, I want to do it!

I think influencers work very hard to make money, so it’s fine to consider influencing a profession. I also think we shouldn’t encourage people to become influencers because it’s increasingly docile to “make it big.”

I think it's great especially if they make an a good impact on people whether it be entertainment, teaching a skill, teaching about politics, etc. They are popular and making money so they should be recognized.

I think it's fine. They offer a value to people in the form of entertaining or informative content. So it makes sense that it would become a new profession. I personally follow a few people that I really enjoy content from so it makes sense to me.

I think internet influencing has rightly become a recognized profession because it combines creativity, marketing, and community-building in ways similar to traditional media careers. It offers new opportunities for people to share their voices and earn a living, but it also comes with instability, intense competition, and mental health challenges. Overall, it’s a legitimate but still-evolving career path that reflects how digital culture is reshaping work.
I don't see anything wrong with it. We all need money more than ever these days, and using your talents for earning purposes as an influencer is as legit as anything else.

I do like that creative outlets online can be a viable profession now, especially since there are so many of them I have watched and followed for years now. There are the annoying influencers within the crowd, of course, but I think that comes with the territory. Overall I think it's a very good scenario.
I think it is a fair thing. They make money and bring entertainment to a lot of people. It is now a viable profession.
I think internet influencers are recognized as engaged in professional work.  However I don't think they command the same respect as schooled professions.
I believe there is a plus to using then to create content on the internet.  By using streamers, bloggers or content creators you can easily promote your business or product.

I really think it depends on the person and what they're influencing him for some it's good and for others it's not so good in my opinion I just really think it depends on the person and what they choose to put out there but I'm glad they're getting paid or compensated for what they're putting out there and their effort is being recognized
Not sure I have an opinion about this yet as this is a fairly new profession. However from what I have heard this type of job can have huge success if the right influencer is hire by some companies.

I am somewhat alarmed. I do appreciate their efforts and them getting their money and better livelihood. The main thing I am concerned about is their influence on other people. The main notable and seen value is their influence on people, they can manipulate people or their content brings no or negative influence.
Some are worth watching and others aren't. Some folks need to lose their platforms while some need to be uplifted in these tough times.
A sign of the times although I find it a bit disturbing. Not because fo the trend itself but rather how much misinformation or misleading information is being peddled by these folks.
If an internet influencer can make money doing it as a profession then it is consider a job. It doesn't matter how people make money as long as it is honest hard earning money.
I think it's completely fine and a valid profession within reason. People often think it's easier than it is and don't know how hard it really it.
if they can make a living wage from it without hurting other people then i don't see any thing wrong with doing it.
I believe that is great since we are creating more room for creativity among young people
Buyer beware, depends on the product, best to compare with several resources, many of them are paid sponsor so they are salespeople
I think that if they can get people to want to follow the em then that is fine.  Personally I’ve never watched or followed any influencers
I think it is cool for everyday people to become content creators. This if they use it for good.
I feel like if people can find a way to make money then go for it.  I like some influencers because real celebrities don't come across as real and many influencers are more relatable.

I'm not a big fan. I think there are some influencers who share important information and create a good sense of community, but I don't love that people are getting paid to influence people to buy things. It feels wrong.
It should be. They are combining acting, marketing, and advertising. I feel it is short lived because companies can easily replace influencers with AI "content creators".

My opinion on internet influencers is varies greatly depending on the content and the personality of the individual. Furthermore, their integrity, or lack thereof influences my opinion as well. I don't like people that are clearly just in it for money and don't offer anything new or refreshing, or take advantage of their audience and position. I think it becoming increasingly recognized as a profession is a slippery slope, because people will start to do anything in order to get views so they  can become one. This may lead to crimes or mentally/physically harmful behaviors. I only like a very small few of creators.
I like it but it does kind of lower the bar on what is considered entertainment.
I think it's a great way for people to create an income source.  If your creative and outgoing it's a great venue to work out of.
It's inevitable. But I worry they will all burnout. The pressure to create content is ever present.

My opinion is a mix of positives and negatives, On the positive side, we get to hear from new and disparate voices that help bring new perspectives to society. On the negative, it creates a society more inclined towards style of substance and consumption.
I think that, even though some are not positive, that it is a valid profession.

I think that creating a path to "influence" without the traditional media has allowed it to be more accessible for more people which is a good thing. However, that also gives a larger voice to people without the oversight of large media groups which can lead to the amplification of extreme theories and opinions. It has also lead to an oversaturation in the market with so many people trying to become influencers.
I don’t mind them. If it makes them happy that’s what matters.
it will happen as AI overtakes most jobs. people will need some place to share ideas

Good when they can share information that will help people.  I personally do not follow because I am not trusting.  But if the public likes this and they can make a profession out of it then it is a good thing.
I have no opinion. I'm open to it and wish I could make more money off this profession.
I am glad there is a new way for people to make money. But it can be dangerous to think they are experts and follow their advice blindly.
I think they are a joker. I think most of them are full of shit and are responsible for the dumbing down of society. I think they need to get a real job.

I think that is fine that people are able to do that as a profession. Some say that it is not a real job but anything you get paid to do is a real life. I do think there is a problem with too many young people pursuing it when not everyone is capable, only a tiny % of people can make it into a stable income.
I think it’s important that they be compensated fairly for their labor. I also think it’s important that kids are taught the reality of the job rather than the glamorized version.
My feeling towards influencers are mostly unfavorable.  I find them shallow and just trying to make money.
No problems with this.  The public decides if it is something they are interested in.  If the demand is there, all good.
It seems as though what used to be considered "selling out" has become the ultimate achievement. It's surprising how envious audiences are of influencers.

Sometimes the videos that influencers make are entertaining/informational, however a lot of times I feel like a lot of influencer content is slop. There can also be a lot of non-genuineness/corruption with influencers, as many will accept shady companies as sponsors, companies such as betterhelp. I feel like being an influencer is definitely a method of making money, but it really only works if you have a lot followers and even then there can be some shadiness to it.
i think they help to promote items

I think it’s interesting to see how the progression on technology has offered a new range of possibilities. I think internet influencers being a legitimate source of income is very progressive. I think that soon the market will become over saturated, but at the moment it’s a cool concept

my opinion on internet "influencers" (e.g. streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized "profession" is that it reminds me of the andy warhol quote about how everyone gets their fifteen minutes of fame... unfortunately nowadays, everyone's getting much more than that...
It seems like that's already a recognized profession. I don't follow these guys but, I have no real objections.

I think it's cool that people can find alternative forms of income and earn money from their creativity and by being at home. However, if everyone is a creator it makes interactions feel less genuine and commercials more prevalent.
It is, but not respected. It’s similar to saying you’re an artist

I am not a fan of this. Influencers are just advertising and we have more than enough of that. It is impossible to tell what is real and authentic about their choices and what is not as profit is always involved. I do not follow them and do not intend to start.
Made it to main stream remember when it was barely a thing now everyone wants to be apart of it

It is already becoming that with monetization of You Tube and Instagram.  It is currently self-regulated.  Building a following is not easy, so viewing this as a profession and gaining the skills to develop a following, offer accurate and beneficial information shoud be recognized as a profession.

I think that it is great especially if they can be informative and helpful to people.  Spreading knowledge is good and that helps everyone in society. It also good for the economy and employments since AI can will possibly take jobs away in the future.

I think it is great, they bring different things to the world. There are some that are political and some are entertaining. I think it is great when I see a person that I see on social media. They are the future stars.

I think most of the influencers have no actual skills, knowledge, or expertise and are fooling people into spending their time and money on them. If it becomes a 'profession' then it should be regulated to people don't fall for incorrect information.
I watch YouTube everyday and have regular creators i enjoy. Since I'm handicapped and can no longer travel I live vicariously through these creators. I value their channels.
If it makes an honest living, it should be recognized.
I like internet influencers. I think there is such a large variety out there, that you can find what you like. For example, I like funny influencers.

I have mixed feelings on the subject. I feel it is the right fit every American to become an entrepreneurs. It is the foundation of this country. However believe there is a lot of mis-information, sensationalism and social pressure put upon readers of their content.
I think its wonderful that so many people are going to be able to have the oportunity to make entertaining audiences their career.

I think it's just a product of content creation becoming more popular for people to consume which translates into an audience to market to. This can be lucrative for a person through social media platform partnerships and brand deals so it only makes sense that it would become recognized as a profession.
I'm not very impressed. I think these types of influencers are frequently too commercial, don't think about what their influence is on people and end up causing a lot of issues.
This opens a new opportunity for a wide variety of people. It also provides much greater options for consuming content than what is professionally created by Hollywood or mainstream media.
I guess it's fine, but I think it's sort of silly. It's not something I would aspire to be.

It makes no sense to me as they have no special knowledge or skills beyond marketing and having a compelling presence.  If it was recognized as a form of entertainment, then maybe I could get on board.  Overall, I find these activities frivolous.
Is very carful watch all other than and he watching is more important

i dont much see how its any different than being on tv just a different medium. i think its easier for the average person to make a name for themselves which levels the playing field ever so slightly in rich vs poor

Depending on the content that is created, some short video creators can be an annoyance. Others such as streamers and bloggers can be useful in the content they create. They could provide useful information to individuals who share the same likes as they do.
I think it’s great that individuals are able to do that and I’m glad they’re making the money rather than paying all of our money toward large companies finding other esto entertain us

The trend in question seems to be in line with the current surge of AI models, as they expand and change in their development. The expansion of AI allows creative, literary and data base functions to be endless, all at the neck and call of even beginners in technology usage. It seems that it is only a matter of time before AI answers before we can even process ourselves as humans with complex solutions being solved at speeds we could only dream of previously.
It's their thing, not my interest but more power to them for finding a way to make money. It has reduced the IQ pf the country though.
I don’t really care. They are stupid.

I think it’s great. If you are able to entertain or advice people who care about what you are saying or doing is commendable. Everybody has an opportunity through social media to expose their ideas, hobbies etc to a larger audience that no one expected.

They are not something that most society should take seriously. They are driven by controversy and "clicks" and would sell out for clout. Unfortunately, society has limited attention spans and "influencers" are a desirable medium for these people.
I think it’s sad. Shouldn’t be an actual job but I see why some people get a following and get enough money from that.
I think internet influencers and bloggers are a necessary profession esp. in todays culture. I think they tell a truth that is bold and needed.
I believe they are not genuine. They do not give accurate opinions, as they don't test the products.

I think it reflects the times we are living in and how big of a deal social media has become. I think it is a valid profession. If people want to give influencers their attention, I don't see an issue with them getting paid for it.

I find it cool that people can make a living out of influencing simply because of how unique it is from a traditional career. There are definitely some things such people need to be aware of when it comes to having a platform but overall I see no issue with it being a recognized profession.
They exploit people for money. Many are hawking the same items. They will say just about anything for likes and money.
I think it’s pretty dumb that it can be a career. A lot of these people use bots to create content that will cause a stir and simply get clicks. It bothers me how little some contribute to society.
It is good for society in general because it helps people dream and strive for more, but also may cause some strife perhaps.

My opinion is that if it's something they love to do and it brings them happiness, then I have no issues with it. So long as they are not doing anything illegal, it's just another job in this world to me.
I like there creativity. They have good talents. They fit very well in what is in todays economy.
I think it's great for them. I wish I was brave enough to be one myself.
I don’t think it’s a good thing, it was great during COVID but now people are becoming reliant on being internet famous and it’s causing them to dumb things

I think it's a good thing for people to be able to do what they love and make a career out of it. These people are usually on social media and social media is so widely used now that most people can easily discover content creators that interest them.
I don't use or pay attention to influencers so I am not aware what they are doing. I guess if they can make some money doing it it is good for them.
It is good to see people create businesses and not rely on big companies.
I don't like influencers. They are all looking for fame. Most of them are very arrogant.

I think if an internet influencer becomes popular enough to become recognizable, they’ve done a great job, and as for it becoming a recognized profession, different times in history have created different professions.
I think it is silly that showing what you made for dinner or dancing to a clip is a job.

I think it shows a degradation in creativity and peoples will. If you look throughout history the large majority have people have thought themselves to be spectators though they spectate. The social media crisis allows people to constantly spectate though under the guise of "social media" with most having the belief it doesn't affect them of course though it does studies show.
These folks took chances and they hit it out of the park.  They created their own way to earn a living. More power to them.
I feel that if these entrepreneurs are talented enough to hook people in, than they deserve to be successful.
It's the wave of the future, go and do whatever you're good at, granted some of this content is pretty stupid and I personally could care less...

They need to get real jobs. If they have real jobs, and try use this just for a side hustle good for them. If they use it to be all about themselves they need to get over themselves. If they use it to promote products, good for them.

I feel pretty neutrally on it. I think it's strange that they've gotten the amount of positive notoriety they have that now has them amongst famous musicians/actors and people of that sort, though. It's a real profession, and I think deserves to be recognized as one, but it's still weird to me to see them invited to the Met Gala and stuff like that.
I’m not all that impressed by influencers. I do my own research when considering a purchase

I think it’s a valid profession. I also think it’s a shame that people can make so much money making a few silly videos. It appears as though less and less people are wanting to take on blue collar jobs because it’s easier to get paid making videos and podcasts in the comfort of your home.
it is a career but should be taken as a hobby not work for people to enjoy

I think the existence of influencers is one of the stupidest things about our current society, and a blot on the internet. The idea that this is a "profession" is completely absurd. Anyone influenced by one of these twits needs a mental check.

Internet "Influencers" is certainly a legitimate profession, though I would consider it more in the advertising and entertainment category.  I do kind of wish short video creators would consider doing longer form work, though - sound bites are causing enough problems as it is.
That they make it easy for free information to be out there, and yet make it harder for those who work professions I where they would charge to either give the information or apply it.

I find it both good and bad. It is always good when people find a niche they can use to make a living, but this type of field is saturated so It can be hard to stand out. If people don't have a back up plan or a bit of luck or skill it isn't necessarily sustainable.
A profession has one basic goal. Provide a way for you to support yourself financially. Anything above and beyond that is just gravy.
I have no issue with the influencers as long as they are factual. Some are to fowl mouthed for my liking. Overall I think it is always good to have more voices to listen to and choose from.
I think there's a lot of low value in the influencer sphere. Most of them are grifters who will sell anything to their audience for a payday.

i believe like most everything there are good and bad influencers.  some are of course honest and others choose to be dishonest. the headlines are usually designed just to have you click.  it can be a profession for many because it requires little to no investment to get started.  what you see try to verify before taking any action

I think that internet influencers play an important role in sharing information and causing lots of influence in people's thought processes. However, they should be monitored because they can spread misinformation juist as easily!

On the one hand, I think it’s great that there are these career options and content to match the needs and interests of all people. However, I do think it’s turning a bit obnoxious and annoying that so many people are trying to become influencers and everything now is viewed as content. It seems being present and living life authentically is becoming harder to come by.

I have mixed feelings. I believe content creators producing good quality content such as teaching something for instance are great and in this case I believe it makes sense to see it as a profession. But when I see people creating content based on stupidity, that's another story.
I love it that people want to put themselves out there to entertain the rest of us
I think it is strange. I understand people can make money doing it. But I do not think it is a good thing for society.
good for them. it's 2025!

I am not a fan of "internet influencer" being seen as a "profession" in increasing amounts. The main issue I have is that involves mainly luck and random popularity, both of which lends to the idea that the "profession" does not involve skills than can be improved or reliably replicated.

Its a new profession. Every technology generates them and, I suppose, people generally think them lesser than their predessors. TV stars are still generally ranked below movie ones in regards to prestige. But
i think it's a great opportunity to gain income
Just like everything, there are good and bad in this profession. Some people are out the doing good things and some are doing not good things.
